questions.question_text: You are asked to create an option in the Service Catalog, which will allow a user to click Get Help and describe the issue they are having. These forms should create incident records, which are automatically routed to the Service Desk. Which method would you use?

discussion.content:
A
Record producers are a type of Catalog Item that creates task based records e.g. incident. Not all Catalog Items are Record producers, so B is incorrect.

questions.question_text: What is the result of the order in which access controls are evaluated?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
In ServiceNow, when a user tries to access a table or field, the access is evaluated first at the table level, and then at the field level. - chatgpt

Selected Answer: A
from more specific to general, A is the correct answer , field first, then table.

Selected Answer: D
Anwser is D People are dumb..

Selected Answer: D
ACL evalutes access to table first (specific to general) then it evaluates field (specific to general)
It's A, rules are evaluated specific to general. This is in the SN textbook.

Selected Answer: D
First at the Table-level (Most specific to most general), then at the Field-level (most specific to most general
for the exam should we give a or d, which option is going to fetch marks for us

comments.content: A is standard security measure, not only in ServiceNow, specific to general

discussion.content:
It's A. As ServiceNow evaluates from specific to general. 
As seen in page 319 in the SNAF eBook.
D is correct. Page 429 of the ServiceNow Administration Fundamentals - Tokyo Edition.

I believe the answer is A. I punched the question into CGPT and it says: "According to ServiceNow Elite, Access Control Lists (ACLs) process within themselves in an order (Roles > Condition > Script)1. If a row level rule and a field level rule exist, both rules must be true before an operation is allowed2. So it seems that ServiceNow would ensure a user has access to the fields in a table before considering their access to the table. I hope this helps!"

Selected Answer: A
Pretty sure it is field then table. You can see the diagram here:
https://www.servicenow.com/community/developer-forum/which-acl-rules-will-be-execute-either-field-level-or-table/m-p/1898751

Also, this link:
https://support.servicenow.com/kb?id=kb_article_view&sysparm_article=KB0541355
was updated as of May 2023, which makes it the most current version under the Utah release. It also states field then table.

comments.content:
Sorry, amending answer to D

From the CSA Prep Course knowledge review section

61. In what order are access controls evaluated?

First at the Table-level (Most specific to most general), then at the Field-level (most specific to most general)

Any chance you could provide a link to the source? I punched the question into CGPT and it says: "According to ServiceNow Elite, Access Control Lists (ACLs) process within themselves in an order (Roles > Condition > Script)1. If a row level rule and a field level rule exist, both rules must be true before an operation is allowed2. So it seems that ServiceNow would ensure a user has access to the fields in a table before considering their access to the table. I hope this helps!"
Also, don't rely on ChatGPT. It's somewhat good at fiction but a lot less accurate when it comes to facts. Just do the research, follow the course materials and speak to experts yourself.

I can't find a page laying this out exactly but it is specified in plain language in the CSA course: Specific to General, Table to Field
You may find these links useful:
https://docs.servicenow.com/en-US/bundle/utah-platform-security/page/administer/contextual-security/concept/access-control-rules.html
https://www.servicenow.com/community/itsm-articles/access-control-list/ta-p/2305018

Hey can't link a source but in the CSA Course on ServiceNow Learning, there is an "access control overview module", the knowledge check quiz for that secion asks this question:

Question 1/3:

In what order are access controls evaluated?

A. First at the Field-level (most specific to most general), then at the Table-level (most specific to most general)

B. First at the Table-level (most specific to most general), then at the Field-level (most specific to most general)

The answer is:
B. First at the Table-level (most specific to most general), then at the Field-level (most specific to most general)

True
as in the Securing Applications Against Unauthorized Users (developer.servicenow):
 
Match the table and field name: x_58872_needit_needit.short_description
Match the parent table and field name: task.short_description
Match any table with the field name: *.short_description
Match the table and any field (wildcard): x_58872_needit_needit.*
Match the parent table and any field (wildcard): task.*
Match any table (wildcard) and any field (wildcard): *.*

discussion.content:

D is correct

Selected Answer: D
D is correct
D is correct

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

Selected Answer: D
Table and then Field
D is the answer

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

choices.B: Ensures user can get to work as quickly as possible
choices.D: Ensures user has access to a table, before evaluating access to a field in the table
choices.C: Ensures user has access to the application, before evaluating access to a module within the application
choices.A: Ensures user has access to the fields in a table, before considering their access to the table

questions.question_text: Which tool graphically displays an infrastructure view for a configuration item (CI) and its relationship with other CIs?

discussion.content: B. In ServiceNow, a "Dependency View" is a graphical representation of the dependencies between Configuration Items (CIs) in an IT infrastructure. A dependency view provides a visual representation of the relationships between CIs and the services

Selected Answer: B
B. Dependency View

Selected Answer: B
The latest link is: https://docs.servicenow.com/bundle/vancouver-servicenow-platform/page/product/business-service-management-map-ng/concept/c_BusinesssServiceManagementMaps.html
B is correct. Page 427 of the ServiceNow Administration Fundamentals - Tokyo Edition.

Selected Answer: B
In ServiceNow, a "Dependency View" is a graphical representation of the dependencies between Configuration Items (CIs) in an IT infrastructure. A dependency view provides a visual representation of the relationships between CIs and the services they support, enabling IT teams to quickly understand the impact of changes, troubleshoot issues, and plan for future improvements.- chatgpt
B is correct answer

Selected Answer: B
correct

User, Task, Incident are core tables in ServiceNow

This is an ambiguous question and therefore should not be in the exam I believe. It looks like there are two definitions of the core table: 1.) tables, which are base tables and doesn't have a parent. In this case c) would be wrong as Incident is a child of task
2.) Core tables are tables that come with the base system. In this case c) is the correct answer
